# WebSocket
# 
Birdeye Real-Time WebSocket Documentation
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#birdeye-real-time-websocket-documentation)
## 
Introduction
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#introduction)
The **Birdeye Real-Time WebSocket** provides real-time updates for cryptocurrency-related events, including **price changes, transactions, OHLCV data, and wallet activity**. This documentation outlines how to connect, subscribe to events, and receive live data updates.
### 
Connection Limits
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#connection-limits)
Each WebSocket **connection** supports:
 * **Price, Transactions, and OHLCV:** Up to **100 tokens per connection**
 * **Wallet Tracking:** **1 address per connection**

WebSocket access is available for **Business Package** subscribers, which includes **500 concurrent connections** by default. For higher limits, consider upgrading to the **Enterprise Package** for more concurrent connections.
# 
Supported Timeframes
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#supported-timeframes)
We support a wide range of timeframes for all chains via the WebSocket API, ranging from 1 minute to 1 month: `1m, 3m, 5m, 15m, 30m, 1H, 2H, 4H, 6H, 8H, 12H, 1D, 3D, 1W, 1M` For Solana, we also support additional smaller intervals: `1s, 15s, 30s` These timeframes can be used in your subscription requests to receive candlestick data at the desired granularity.
## 
Code Example
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#code-example)
Checkout this Github file for an example: <https://github.com/birdeye-so/tradingview-example-js-api/blob/main/websocket_example.js#L62-L65>
Sample for new-pair on javascript <https://github.com/TheNang2710/bds-public/blob/main/new-pair-simple.js>
Sample code for ohlcv on Go <https://github.com/TheNang2710/bds-public/blob/main/go/ws_price.go>
## 
WebSocket URL:
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#websocket-url)
```
wss://public-api.birdeye.so/socket/solana?x-api-key=YOUR-API-KEY
```

### 
Header
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#header)
Key | Value 
---|--- 
`Origin` | ws://public-api.birdeye.so 
`Sec-WebSocket-Origin` | ws://public-api.birdeye.so 
`Sec-WebSocket-Protocol` | echo-protocol 
**Note:**
 * Replace `<chain>` with the desired blockchain identifier (e.g., `solana` for the Solana blockchain, ethereum for the Ethereum blockchain) and `<api_key>` with your Birdeye API key.
 * Add `echo-protocol` to your request header.

## 
Subscription and Unsubscription
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#subscription-and-unsubscription)
To receive real-time updates, you need to subscribe to specific events using subscription messages. The example code above demonstrates how to send a subscription message to receive price updates for a specific currency pair.
## 
Supported WebSocket Events
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#supported-websocket-events)
Birdeye Real-Time WebSocket supports the following subscription types:
### 
**Subscription Events**
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#subscription-events)
**Subscription Type** | **Description** 
---|--- 
`SUBSCRIBE_PRICE` | Subscribe to receive real-time price updates for tokens or token pairs. 
`SUBSCRIBE_BASE_QUOTE_PRICE` | Subscribe to receive real-time updates about price changes for any token pairs without needing to input a specific pair address 
`SUBSCRIBE_TXS` | Subscribe to receive real-time transaction updates for tokens or token pairs. 
`SUBSCRIBE_TOKEN_NEW_LISTING` | Subscribe to real-time updates about new token listings. 
`SUBSCRIBE_NEW_PAIR` | Subscribe to receive real-time updates about new pairs. 
`SUBSCRIBE_LARGE_TRADE_TXS` | Subscribe to large trade transactions filtered by specified volume thresholds in USD. 
`SUBSCRIBE_WALLET_TXS` | Subscribe to real-time updates for transactions involving a specific wallet address; useful for tracking all token transactions of a given address. 
`SUBSCRIBE_TOKEN_STATS` | Subscribe to real-time updates for token overview data 
### 
**Unsubscription Events**
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#unsubscription-events)
The WebSocket also supports unsubscription with the following message values:
 * **`UNSUBSCRIBE_NEW_PAIR`**
 * **`UNSUBSCRIBE_PRICE`**
 * **`UNSUBSCRIBE_BASE_QUOTE_PRICE`**
 * **`UNSUBSCRIBE_LARGE_TRADE_TXS`**
 * **`UNSUBSCRIBE_TOKEN_NEW_LISTING`**
 * **`UNSUBSCRIBE_TXS`**
 * **`UNSUBSCRIBE_WALLET_TXS`**
 * **`TOKEN_STATS_DATA`**

For example:
```
msg = {
   type: "UNSUBSCRIBE_TXS"
}
```

## 
Connection Instructions
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#connection-instructions)
To establish a WebSocket connection to the Birdeye Real-Time API, you can use various WebSocket client libraries available for different programming languages.
Here's an example using Node.js:
JavaScript
```
const WebSocketClient = require('websocket').client;
const util = require("util");

const client = new WebSocketClient();

client.on('connectFailed', function (error) {
    console.log('Connect Error: ' + error.toString());
});

client.on('connect', function (connection) {
    console.log('WebSocket Client Connected');

    connection.on('error', function (error) {
        console.log("Connection Error: " + error.toString());
    });

    connection.on('close', function () {
        console.log('WebSocket Connection Closed');
    });

    connection.on('message', function (message) {
        if (message.type === 'utf8') {
            console.log("Received: '" + message.utf8Data + "'");
            // Process received data here
        }
    });

    // Send subscription message here
    const subscriptionMsg = {
        type: "SUBSCRIBE_PRICE",
        data: {
            chartType: "1m",
            currency: "pair",
            address: "FmKAfMMnxRMaqG1c4emgA4AhaThi4LQ4m2A12hwoTibb"
        }
    };

    connection.send(JSON.stringify(subscriptionMsg));
});

// Connect to Birdeye WebSocket
client.connect(util.format('wss://public-api.birdeye.so/socket/<chain>?x-api-key=<api_key>'), 'echo-protocol', "https://birdeye.so");
```

## 
Message Format
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#message-format)
WebSocket messages are exchanged in **JSON format** , consisting of:
 * **`type`**: Specifies the subscription type (e.g.,`"SUBSCRIBE_PRICE"`).
 * **`data`**: Contains the relevant subscription details.

* * *
## 
Real-Time Data
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#real-time-data)
Once subscribed, real-time updates are received in **JSON format** , containing relevant information based on the subscribed event. The structure of the response varies depending on the event type.
* * *
## 
Error Handling
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#error-handling)
WebSocket connections may encounter **errors** due to network instability, API limits, or invalid requests. To ensure smooth operation:
 * **Monitor error events** and handle them gracefully.
 * **Implement automatic reconnection** in case of connection failures.

* * *
## 
Closing & Reconnecting
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#closing--reconnecting)
To properly close a WebSocket connection, ensure a **graceful shutdown**. If the connection is lost unexpectedly, implement a **reconnection mechanism** to restore subscriptions automatically.
Recommended **reconnection strategy** :
 * **Use exponential backoff** to manage reconnection attempts.
 * **Verify network connectivity** before retrying.
 * **Re-subscribe to previous events** upon reconnection.

* * *
## 
Security Considerations
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#security-considerations)
 * **Keep API keys secure** and avoid exposing them in public repositories or front-end code.
 * **Use environment variables** to store sensitive credentials.
 * **Monitor WebSocket usage** to detect unauthorized access.

## 
Connection Stability: Ping-Pong and Reconnection Strategy
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/websocket#connection-stability-ping-pong-and-reconnection-strategy)
To ensure long-lived and reliable WebSocket connections‚Äîespecially for streaming real-time price updates‚Äîwe recommend implementing a ping-pong mechanism alongside a reconnection strategy.
WebSocket connections can silently drop due to network issues, timeouts, or intermediate proxies. A heartbeat system using ping-pong messages helps detect these drops and recover gracefully.
üîÅ Implementing Ping-Pong Birdeye WebSocket servers support standard WebSocket ping/pong frames.
**Client-Side (Example in JavaScript):**
JavaScript
```
const WebSocketClient = require('websocket').client;
const util = require("util");

const client = new WebSocketClient();

client.on('connectFailed', function (error) {
    console.log('Connect Error: ' + error.toString());
});

client.on('connect', function (connection) {
    connection.on('error', function (error) {
        console.log("Connection Error: " + error.toString());
    });

    connection.on('close', function () {
        console.log('WebSocket Connection Closed');
    });

    connection.on('message', function (message) {
        if (message.type === 'utf8') {
            console.log("Received: '" + message.utf8Data + "'");
            // Process received data here
        }
    });

    connection.on('ping', function () {
        connection.pong()
    });

    // Send subscription message here
    const subscriptionMsg = {
        type: "SUBSCRIBE_PRICE",
        data: {
            chartType: "1m",
            currency: "pair",
            address: "FmKAfMMnxRMaqG1c4emgA4AhaThi4LQ4m2A12hwoTibb"
        }
    };

    connection.send(JSON.stringify(subscriptionMsg));
});

// Connect to Birdeye WebSocket
const chain = "solana"; // Example chain
const apiKey = "<your_api_key_here>";
const wsUrl = util.format('wss://public-api.birdeye.so/socket/%s?x-api-key=%s', chain, apiKey);

client.connect(wsUrl, 'echo-protocol', "https://birdeye.so");
```

Notes:
 * The server may also initiate pings. Make sure your client responds with a pong automatically or manually, depending on the WebSocket library you‚Äôre using.
 * Adjust ping intervals based on your latency tolerance and expected traffic volume.
 * Always clear timeouts and intervals when closing or reconnecting.

# How Backpack Wallet delivered Day-1 real-time trading on Monad with Birdeye API
At Monad mainnet launch, Backpack Wallet shipped a production-ready trading experience ‚Äì powered by a real-time onchain data layer built with Birdeye.
4 min 
read
!How Backpack Wallet delivered Day-1 real-time trading on Monad with Birdeye API
When a new network launches, user expectations don‚Äôt reset to ‚Äúbeta.‚Äù In an ecosystem-native wallet, every interaction leads to a real onchain action ‚Äî discovering new tokens, swapping into emerging assets, or participating in early market activity. Users expect speed, clarity, and confidence from the first interaction.
For Backpack Wallet‚Äôs Monad mainnet launch, that meant shipping **action-ready experiences from Day 1** : fast token discovery, accurate real-time pricing, responsive charts, and trustworthy token context ‚Äî all critical as new assets and liquidity rapidly emerged.
To meet that bar on a tight launch timeline, Backpack partnered with Birdeye as a core component of its real-time onchain data layer.
### The challenge ‚Äî shipping trading-grade UX at network launch
Monad‚Äôs mainnet launch was a key ecosystem moment for Backpack. With QA and code-freeze deadlines approaching, the wallet needed to support **real economic activity immediately** , not incremental enablement post-launch.
Backpack planned to use Birdeye‚Äôs APIs for most trading-related functionality inside the wallet. This included:
 * Discovering newly launched and trending tokens
 * Powering zero-fee in-wallet swaps with accurate pricing and liquidity context
 * Rendering responsive charts as markets formed
 * Giving users enough information to act confidently during volatile early conditions

Early network launches are inherently dynamic. Token metadata evolves quickly, liquidity shifts rapidly, and incomplete or delayed data can undermine user confidence ‚Äî particularly when users are swapping or trading newly launched assets.
For the Monad mainnet launch, Backpack also rolled out a dedicated in-wallet launch campaign and collaborated closely with Monad-native token launchpads such as Nad.fun, further increasing early onchain activity and raising the bar for real-time, reliable data. Backpack required an onchain data provider that could support real-time updates, fast integration, and production reliability from Day 1.
### The solution ‚Äî real-time data powering swaps, discovery, and markets
Backpack has built its reputation as a trading-first wallet in the Solana ecosystem, where real-time data is table stakes. To extend that same standard to Monad, Backpack mapped its core trading experiences directly to Birdeye‚Äôs onchain data infrastructure.
Key integrations included:
 * **Real-time multi-token pricing and liquidity** , allowing Backpack to keep token lists current as new assets and liquidity emerged during launch
 * **Token overview and metadata** , providing traders with market signals such as volume, liquidity, buy/sell activity, market capitalization, and supply
 * **Historical price data** , enabling responsive in-wallet charting by timestamp
 * **Trending token discovery** , surfacing where trading activity was concentrating across short-term time windows

To accelerate time-to-market, Birdeye enabled Monad support on its existing API infrastructure. This allowed Backpack to integrate, test, and validate using familiar endpoints ‚Äî without waiting for separate tooling or environments ‚Äî helping the team meet launch timelines with confidence.
### The outcome ‚Äî **a smoother Day-1 trading experience**
With Birdeye integrated into its onchain data layer, Backpack delivered a smoother and more confident Day-1 trading experience on Monad: real-time pricing and liquidity, responsive charting, and token pages that matched trader expectations ‚Äî even during an incentive-driven launch period.
Throughout the launch process, Birdeye worked closely with Backpack to support integration questions and trending-token updates as the ecosystem evolved. The collaboration reflects a shared focus on shipping production-ready trading experiences, even as new networks come online.
> _‚ÄúBirdeye plays an important role in Backpack‚Äôs onchain data layer. Their API provides reliable token information across multiple networks, enabling real-time pricing and insights within Backpack Wallet. The integration has been smooth, and their team is always quick to support.‚Äù_ ‚Äî Armani Ferrante, Founder & CEO, Backpack
### Looking ahead
Following the Monad launch, Backpack plans to continue expanding its real-time data infrastructure as it supports additional networks and trading experiences. With a production-grade onchain data layer in place, Backpack is positioned to ship launch-day-ready trading experiences without compromising speed, accuracy, or user trust.

# Filter, Analyze, and Discover Token Activity with Trades by Volume (V3)
New API Trades ‚Äì Transactions by Volume (V3) builds on Trades ‚Äì Token (V3) API, adding volume-based filtering and an unlimited time range for deeper, more flexible analysis.
2 min 
read
!Filter, Analyze, and Discover Token Activity with Trades by Volume \(V3\)
Understanding what drives token movement requires more than just tracking transactions; it means knowing which trades actually matter. With Trades ‚Äì Transactions by Volume (V3), Birdeye Data Services gives developers the ability to filter token trades by size, timeframe, and currency type to uncover meaningful activity on Solana.
This new version builds on Trades ‚Äì Token (V3), adding volume-based filtering and an unlimited time range for deeper, more flexible analysis of token behavior and market dynamics.
## What‚Äôs New
The Trades ‚Äì Transactions by Volume (V3) API returns a list of trades for a specified token, now with full control over trade size and filtering criteria. You can define:
 * **`min_volume`**and**`max_volume`**to isolate trades within your desired range
 * **`volume_type`**to choose between USD or token amount
 * **`limit`**to query up to 500 trades per request

Unlike the previous version, this API supports unlimited time ranges, enabling both real-time and historical volume analysis at scale.
## Why It Matters
Trade volume tells the real story behind market activity. Whether you are identifying whale movements, tracking trading momentum, or detecting sudden liquidity surges, Trades by Volume (V3) delivers the precision needed to focus on significant trades instead of noise.
With this endpoint, developers can:
 * Detect abnormal spikes in trading activity
 * Focus on large trades that move markets
 * Identify volume trends for token health and liquidity research

## Start Building Today
Using it is simple: send a GET request to `/defi/v3/trades/token-by-volume` with your target token. Add `**min_volume**`and`**max_volume**`to set your trade range, choose`**volume_type**`as either`usd` or `token_amount`, and get up to 500 trades in one call ‚Äî complete with full trade details and timestamps.

# Black Friday 4-in-1 Special Offers: Biggest Promotion of the Year
Starting 28 November, we are launching Black Friday Special Offers, a 4-in-1 program designed to give every developer more value across every tier of BDS.

read
!Black Friday 4-in-1 Special Offers: Biggest Promotion of the Year
This year, Birdeye Data Services is closing 2025 with our most comprehensive upgrade yet. Starting **28 November** , we are launching **Black Friday Special Offers** , a 4-in-1 program designed to give every developer more value across every tier of BDS.
One part of the program runs for one month (the 30% discount), while the other three upgrades are long-term improvements that will continue beyond the campaign window.
## 1. 30% Off All Paid Plans for New Users (28 Nov ‚Äì 28 Dec Only)
During this one-month period, all new paid users receive **30% off** their **first month**.
 * Lite: $39 ‚Üí $27.3
 * Starter: $99 ‚Üí $69.3
 * Premium: $199 ‚Üí $139.3
 * Premium Plus: $250 ‚Üí $175
 * Business: $699 ‚Üí $489.3 

The subscription renews at standard pricing from the second month onward. **No refund** will be made for discounted purchases. This limited-time offer gives teams a low-commitment way to explore higher tiers at a reduced cost.
## 2. Up to 67% More Compute Units Across Paid Plans 
In addition to the seasonal discount, we are increasing Compute Unit allowances across all paid plans. These expanded CU limits will remain in place **after** the Black Friday period.
New CU allowances:
 * Starter: 3M ‚Üí 5M CUs
 * Premium: 10M ‚Üí 15M CUs 
 * Premium Plus: 15M ‚Üí 20M CUs 
 * Business: 70M ‚Üí 100M CUs 

These increases allow developers to test larger workloads, handle more traffic, and scale faster without hitting compute ceilings. Usage increase will be applied to your **upcoming billing cycle**.
## 3. Introducing the Lite Plan 
We are also launching **Lite** , a new entry plan created for smaller projects and lightweight use cases. This plan will remain available after the campaign.
**Lite Plan**
 * Price: $39/month (will be $27.3 for the first month during the one-month Black Friday Special Offers)
 * CU: 1.5M
 * Rate limit: 15 RPS

Ideal for students, early prototypes, small personal projects, and builders who want to explore BDS at the lowest price point.
## 4. Standard Plan Expansion to 48 APIs
The Standard (Free) plan now includes **48 APIs** , up from 21. This represents a long-term expansion of the free tier and is available beyond the one-month campaign.
The upgrade gives more builders access to core API coverage across tokens, trades, pricing, OHLCV, and wallet data ‚Äî making it possible to build meaningful prototypes without upgrading immediately.
## The Complete 4-in-1 Program at a Glance
Four improvements launched together, but only one is time-limited:
 1. **30% off** all paid plans for new users (28 Nov ‚Äì 28 Dec only)
 2. **Up to 67% more compute units** across paid plans 
 3. **New Lite plan** for smaller-scale and trial builds 
 4. **Standard plan expanded** from 21 ‚Üí 48 APIs 

A seasonal discount plus three lasting upgrades to strengthen the BDS ecosystem moving forward.
## Build More with BDS This Season
Whether you are scaling production workloads or testing your first idea, Black Friday Special Offers make this the best moment to upgrade, explore, and expand with BDS.
The discount period runs from **28 November to 28 December** , so grab your chance now!

Birdeye Data Services now supports Fogo APIs with 30+ endpoints for price, OHLCV, trades, transactions, and market lists ‚Äì built for dashboards, bots, explorers, and DeFi apps. WebSockets coming soon.
3 min 
read
!Fogo Data APIs Are Now Live on Birdeye Data Services
Birdeye Data Services now supports Fogo APIs, giving builders a fast way to pull trading-grade onchain data for dashboards, bots, explorers, analytics, and DeFi apps.
Instead of spinning up and maintaining your own indexing stack, you can plug into BDS and get normalized data through a single interface, so your product logic stays clean even as you scale across chains.
**Release date:** January 12, 2026
**Note:** WebSocket support for Fogo is coming soon.
### What BDS Supports on Fogo
Fogo apps tend to be latency-sensitive: traders want live updates, bots need reliable triggers, and analytics tools can‚Äôt lag behind market moves. With this release, BDS provides the building blocks you need to ship those experiences on Fogo today.
#### Fogo REST APIs (Available Now)
BDS supports 30+ Fogo endpoints, covering the most-used market and activity data surfaces:
 * Price & OHLCV for tokens and pairs (incl. base/quote candles)
 * Token overview + metadata
 * Trade + market data, including derived metrics such as price change and volume change
 * Transactions across multiple views: 
 * by token
 * by pair
 * by trader
 * by time range
 * by latest block
 * Market lists and ecosystem routing surfaces: 
 * trending tokens
 * top traders
 * other ranking lists used for discovery and monitoring

This is enough to power:
 * token pages and charting
 * ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs moving‚Äù dashboards
 * trader leaderboards
 * bot logic that reacts to trades / flows
 * monitoring and alert systems

Start building on Fogo with Birdeye Price API
#### Fogo WebSocket Streaming (Coming Soon)
REST coverage gets you live products quickly, but for real-time trading UX and bot triggers, streaming matters.
WebSocket support for Fogo will be released soon, enabling low-latency feeds for live dashboards, alerts, and automated strategies.
Once it‚Äôs live, we‚Äôll publish supported subscription types and payload formats in the WebSocket docs.
### Why This Matters
If you‚Äôre building on a performance chain like Fogo, your product can‚Äôt be held back by the data layer.
BDS helps teams:
 * ship faster without building custom indexing infra
 * keep integrations simple with a chain-agnostic API design
 * rely on consistent formats across endpoints (easier analytics + multi-chain expansion)
 * scale data consumption as usage ramps up

### Start Building on Fogo
 1. Get an API key via the BDS dashboard
 2. Call REST endpoints with your API key and set the chain to `Fogo`

# Fetch Better Wallet Token Balance with Token Balance V2 API
Introducing Wallet Token Balance v2 API ‚Äî the newest and most complete way to fetch token balances from Solana wallets.
2 min 
read
!Fetch Better Wallet Token Balance with Token Balance V2 API
Introducing Wallet Token Balance v2 API ‚Äî the newest and most complete way to fetch token balances from Solana wallets.

This upgraded endpoint is designed to replace the older Wallet Token Balance (beta), offering more structured outputs and better compatibility with other wallet APIs like Wallet Current Net Worth (which should replace the older Wallet Portfolio beta).
## What It Does
The Wallet Token Balance v2 API returns a full snapshot of a wallet‚Äôs token balances, including:
 * Human-readable token amounts (no more manual decimal calculations)
 * USD value of each token held
 * Raw balances in base units
 * Rich token metadata (symbol, name, address, decimals, etc.)

This gives developers clean, reliable data to display portfolio breakdowns without stitching together multiple data sources.
## How to Use It
You can query any Solana wallet and retrieve balances for a list of tokens all at once.
Because the output includes formatted amounts, USD values, and token metadata, it pairs perfectly with the Wallet Current Net Worth API to build full portfolio views ‚Äî from balance overviews to net worth summaries ‚Äî without extra calculation or processing.
We recommend using Wallet Token Balance v2 in place of Wallet Token Balance (beta) going forward.
## Start Building Today
Wallet Token Balance v2 is live now and ready to power your Solana wallet features.

With this release, Aptos developers get the same BDS experience teams already rely on across other supported chains: fast, normalized, production-grade blockchain data, delivered through a chain-agnostic data API.
### What BDS Supports on Aptos
BDS provides a complete Aptos data API suite, covering the primitives most applications need from day one.
#### Aptos REST APIs
Use BDS REST APIs to power:
 * Real-time token pricing (single + batch)
 * Historical pricing
 * OHLCV candles (token, pair, base/quote)
 * Trades & transaction feeds (token-level, pair-level, filtered views)
 * All-time and historical trade data
 * Derived trade metrics (price change, volume change over time)
 * Token discovery & search (token lists, filtering, search)
 * Token metadata & overviews (symbol, name, decimals, market stats)
 * Pair & liquidity context for DEX markets

This setup supports everything from a simple Aptos token price page to a full-featured Aptos trading terminal, without stitching together multiple data providers.
#### Aptos WebSocket Streaming
For low-latency and real-time use cases, BDS WebSockets stream live Aptos events including:
 * Live price / OHLCV updates
 * Real-time trades / tx updates
 * Base-quote price streams
 * New pair signals
 * Large trade tracking
 * Wallet activity streams

If you‚Äôre building alerts, trading bots, real-time dashboards, or onchain monitoring tools, this is the backbone.
### **Why This Matters for Builders**
Aptos is designed for high throughput and low latency, using a pipelined execution model and parallel transaction processing (Block-STM). While this architecture unlocks strong onchain performance, applications still depend on clean, real-time Aptos data to fully leverage that speed.
BDS complements Aptos by providing:
 * Reliable Aptos market data coverage without maintaining custom indexers
 * Consistent API response formats across chains, simplifying multi-chain deployments
 * Unified access to historical and real-time blockchain data
 * Infrastructure that scales as Aptos ecosystem activity grows

### Start building on Aptos

# 2025 Year in Review: Powering Internet Capital Markets with Birdeye Data Services
In 2025, Birdeye Data Services (BDS) scaled its onchain data infrastructure to support builders, teams, and institutions operating across the crypto stack. From granular market data to wallet-level intelligence and Day-1 chain readiness, BDS became a foundational layer behind many of the fastest-moving crypto products today.
4 min 
read
!2025 Year in Review: Powering Internet Capital Markets with Birdeye Data Services
Empowering Internet Capital Markets takes more than charts.
It takes infrastructure that is real-time, reliable, and production-ready, built not just for demos but for real users, real capital, and real market pressure.
In 2025, **Birdeye Data Services (BDS)** scaled its onchain data infrastructure to support builders, teams, and institutions operating across the crypto stack. From granular market data to wallet-level intelligence and Day-1 chain readiness, BDS became a foundational layer behind many of the fastest-moving crypto products today.
This is what we shipped.
### BDS in 2025: By the Numbers
By the end of 2025, Birdeye Data Services had grown into a widely adopted data layer for onchain markets:
 * **10,000+** builders and teams actively using BDS
 * 74 APIs and 8 WebSocket streams live as of December 2025
 * Coverage across Solana, Sui, and major EVM networks

Behind every ‚Äúinstant‚Äù trading interface, analytics dashboard, or onchain application is data that needs to be accurate, fast, and consistently available. BDS is built to be that layer.
### Wallet Data, Made Production-Ready
Wallet data is foundational to onchain analytics ‚Äî but historically, it has been fragmented, slow, and difficult to operationalize at scale.
In 2025, BDS shipped a full suite of **wallet-grade APIs on Solana** , enabling teams to build robust wallet intelligence into their products:
 * PnL and performance tracking
 * Balance change and net worth analysis
 * Portfolio-level breakdowns

These APIs power trader dashboards, wallet analytics tools, and institutional reporting, delivering accurate, structured wallet data without teams having to build and maintain complex indexing pipelines themselves.
### Granular, Real-Time Market Data
Market data only becomes alpha when it is **granular and real time**. Throughout 2025, BDS expanded its market and DeFi data surface to support high-frequency use cases and deeper analysis:
 * OHLCV data at 1s, 15s, and 30s intervals (via both REST APIs and WebSockets)
 * Real-time token stats APIs and streams
 * All-time trades APIs for deep historical analysis
 * Meme token lists and detailed metadata across Solana, BNB Chain, and Monad

The result: lower latency, higher signal, and data that can actually keep up with fast-moving onchain markets.
### Day-1 Chain Readiness: Monad Mainnet
When new networks launch, data cannot lag behind.
For the **Monad mainnet** , Birdeye Data Services shipped **on day one** , providing builders with immediate access to a full data surface:
 * 39 REST APIs
 * 7 WebSocket types

Live from block one, BDS ensured that teams could ship trading interfaces, analytics, and tooling without waiting weeks for basic data coverage.
### Shipping with Ecosystems
BDS didn‚Äôt just ship APIs. We shipped _**with ecosystems**_.
In 2025, Birdeye supported builders globally through partnerships and programs, including:
 * **Startup Villages** with Superteam chapters across Japan, Indonesia, Korea, and Vietnam
 * **Cypherpunk Global Hackathon** with Colosseum
 * **Base Build** , an exclusive program supporting builders on Base
 * **Orbit Earn** , offering tailored support for participating teams

These programs weren‚Äôt just about exposure. They were about giving builders reliable infrastructure they could trust while shipping real products.
### Research as Infrastructure
Data without interpretation is just noise.
In 2025, **Birdeye Research** published two flagship reports grounded in real onchain data, designed to help builders, investors, and institutions understand where crypto markets are heading:
 * **From DeFi Backbone to Payment Disruptor: How Stablecoins Evolve** Co-authored with Perena and MoonPay, exploring the growing role of stablecoins in payments and onchain finance.
 * **The Everything-Onchain Era: A RWA Spectrum Report** Co-authored with R3, with strategic support from Centrifuge and xStocks, mapping the expansion of real-world assets and tokenized financial products onchain.

### Looking Ahead: Birdeye Peak
And in 2025, we also took the first step up-market.
Announced at Breakpoint 2025, **Birdeye Peak** is our institutional market intelligence platform, designed for funds, institutions, and professional market participants.
Birdeye Peak brings structured, reliable, and actionable insights across digital asset markets, with a clear ambition: to become the **Bloomberg Terminal for crypto**.
The closed beta is now open for registration at **birdeye.so/peak**
### 2025 Built the Foundation
2025 was about laying the rails.
From trader tooling to institutional infrastructure, Birdeye Data Services is building the foundation for **Internet Capital Markets** : markets that are open, onchain, and real time by default.
2026 is about scale.

### Introduction to the Wallet ‚Äî Balance Change API
The Wallet ‚Äî Balance Change API retrieves the balance change history of any Solana wallet, with optional token-level filtering. Designed for on-chain analytics, dashboards, and monitoring tools, it offers rich query parameters to deliver the exact data you need.

With this endpoint, projects can:
 * Calculate the netflow (inflow value minus outflow value) of wallets to measure the overall balance impact.
 * Monitor wallet inflows and outflows of wallets over time, broken down by specific SPL tokens or SOL, for wallet activity analysis.
 * Flag suspicious activity if there are sudden balance increases or large outflows from wallets or malicious token transfers.
 * Retrieve token-specific balance changes over a defined time window to help users or institutions calculate gains/losses in their portfolio and generate reports.

### Why Birdeye‚Äôs API leads
Our Wallet ‚Äî Balance Change API provides a precise and flexible solution for tracking token-level net balance changes. Unlike other providers, it lets you query a wallet‚Äôs full balance history ‚Äî from the genesis block to the present ‚Äî without decoding transactions manually.

# Token Holder Distribution: Deep Insights Into Token Supply Concentration on Solana
Token Holder Distribution endpoint returns holder distribution statistics based on share of total supply.
3 min 
read
!Token Holder Distribution: Deep Insights Into Token Supply Concentration on Solana
Understanding who holds a token and how supply is distributed across wallets is critical for evaluating token health, decentralization, and risk. As on-chain ecosystems mature, developers and analysts need clearer visibility into holder concentration and distribution dynamics.
To support these use cases, Birdeye Data Services is introducing a new analytics endpoint: **Token Holder Distribution**.
This API provides a structured breakdown of how a token‚Äôs supply is distributed across holders on Solana, enabling developers to build richer analytics for dashboards, token profiles, risk assessment tools, and research platforms.
## **What Token Holder Distribution Provides**
The **Token Holder Distribution** endpoint returns aggregated holder distribution statistics based on share of total supply, supporting both **percentage-based ranges** and **top holder** views.
For a given token mint address, developers can retrieve:
 * Holder distribution by specified percentage-of-supply ranges or top holders
 * Number of wallets in each specified range
 * Supply concentration insights without scanning individual holders
 * Optional wallet lists for a selected percentage range when `include_list=true`

By default, results are returned in **percent-based distribution mode**.
## **Flexible Range Filtering and Wallet Drilldowns**
To support token analytics and research workflows, **Token Holder Distribution** **API** supports both **range-based** and **top-based** holder analysis, with flexible configuration options:
 * Define custom holder segments using `min_percent` and `max_percent` for percentage-based analysis
 * Use `top` mode to retrieve distribution data for top holders by share of total supply
 * Optionally enable `include_list=true` to retrieve wallet addresses for a specified range
 * Use `offset` and `limit` parameters to paginate large holder segments efficiently

These options allow developers to quickly isolate whale segments, analyze mid-tier holder groups, or inspect long-tail ownership without scanning full holder lists.
## **How It Complements the Holder API Suite**
The new **Token Holder Distribution** API adds a supply-level view to Birdeye‚Äôs Holder Analytics, complementing existing wallet-focused holder endpoints and enabling analysis beyond individual balances.
With this release, Birdeye‚Äôs **Holder API suite** includes:
 * **Token Holder** for retrieving the top holders of a specified token
 * **Token Holder (Batch)** for retrieving token balances for a specified list of wallet owners
 * **Token Holder Distribution** for analyzing how a token‚Äôs total supply is distributed across holders by specified percentage-of-supply ranges or top holder views

Together, these APIs give developers a complete toolkit to analyze holder concentration and supply distribution, from identifying top holders and inspecting specific wallet groups to understanding overall supply structure.
## **Start Building**
Getting started is straightforward. Send a `GET` request to the **Token Holder Distribution** endpoint with a token mint address, and receive a ready-to-use breakdown of holder distribution using either percentage-based ranges or top holder views.
**Documentation:** Link
The response is optimized for direct use in dashboards, token profile pages, and analytical workflows.

# Wallet PnL Details: Full Profit and Loss Breakdown for Solana Wallets
Wallet PnL Details endpoint returns the full PnL summary of any Solana wallet along with detailed profit and loss metrics for up to 100 individual tokens.
3 min 
read
!Wallet PnL Details: Full Profit and Loss Breakdown for Solana Wallets

As on-chain trading activity grows, developers need more granular and reliable ways to evaluate wallet performance. After releasing the Wallet PnL Summary API, which provides a high-level view of profitability across an entire wallet, Birdeye Data Services is expanding the suite with a deeper analytics tool: **Wallet PnL Details**.
This new endpoint returns the full PnL summary of any Solana wallet along with detailed profit and loss metrics for up to 100 individual tokens. It is ideal for dashboards, portfolio analytics, trader profiles, and research tools that require visibility beyond aggregate statistics.
## What Wallet PnL Details Provides
Wallet PnL Details builds on the summary API by including a richer view of how each token contributes to the wallet‚Äôs overall performance. For every token included, developers can retrieve:
 * Realized and unrealized PnL
 * Total cashflow
 * Buy and sell quantity
 * Last trade timestamp
 * Trade count and activity indicators

The endpoint returns both the top-level PnL summary and the token-by-token breakdown in a single call, giving developers a complete performance picture with minimal processing.
## Flexible Sorting and Filtering
To support analytics workflows, Wallet PnL Details includes customization options:
 * Sort results by `last_trade` to surface the most recently active tokens
 * Optionally filter the response by token mint address to focus on specific assets

These features help developers quickly identify active positions, dormant holdings, or tokens driving the majority of performance.
## How It Complements the PnL API Suite
The new Wallet PnL Details API replaces the now deprecated Wallet PnL (Per Token). With this release, Birdeye‚Äôs PnL toolkit now includes:
 * Wallet PnL Summary for an overall profitability snapshot
 * Wallet PnL (Per Wallet) for comparing up to 50 wallets for a single token
 * Wallet PnL Details for deep, multi-token performance breakdowns

Together, these APIs give developers the flexibility to evaluate trading performance at any scale, from individual positions to entire wallets.
## Start Building
Using Wallet PnL Details is simple. Send a POST request to `/wallet/v2/pnl/details` with a Solana wallet address. The response includes the overall summary plus detailed metrics for up to 100 tokens, ready for display in dashboards or further analysis.

# Introducing the Wallet PnL API Combo: Track Realized & Unrealized Gains on Solana
BDS is making wallet analytics more transparent and accessible with the launch of our new Wallet PnL API combo on Solana.
3 min 
read
!Introducing the Wallet PnL API Combo: Track Realized & Unrealized Gains on Solana
At Birdeye Data Services, we‚Äôre making wallet analytics more transparent and accessible with the launch of our new Wallet PnL API combo on Solana.
These APIs make it easy to query profit and loss (PnL) data for any Solana wallet ‚Äî including trade counts, token quantities, cashflows, and both realized and unrealized PnL. This combo includes: Wallet PnL per Token and Wallet PnL per Wallet.
## What You Get from Wallet PnL
The Wallet PnL API combo goes beyond balances and snapshots. It returns detailed performance data that paints the full picture of a wallet‚Äôs trading activity, including:
 * Trade count: Total number of buy and sell transactions per token
 * Quantity: Token amounts bought, held or sold
 * Cashflow: Net inflows and outflows in USD
 * PnL: Realized and unrealized gains or losses, in both USD value and %
 * Pricing: Token prices at trade execution and current market price

## PnL per Token and per Wallet
The Wallet PnL API Combo gives you two powerful ways to analyze performance ‚Äî by tokens inside a wallet, or by wallets holding a token. 
 * With Wallet PnL per Token, you can query PnL of up to 50 tokens in one wallet
 * With Wallet PnL per Wallet, you get PnL of up to 50 wallets for one token.

With these two endpoints, you can go both deep (token-level detail inside one wallet) and wide (wallet-level comparisons for one token) ‚Äî giving you full flexibility for performance analytics.
## Why It Matters
PnL is one of the most requested metrics from developers building dashboards, portfolio trackers, whale trackers, and trading tools. Until now, calculating it meant stitching together trades, prices, and balances manually ‚Äî a time-consuming process prone to errors.
With Wallet PnL, Birdeye does the heavy lifting. You get ready-to-use, structured PnL data, so you can focus on delivering the insights your users actually care about: who‚Äôs profitable, which tokens are driving gains or losses, and how strategies are performing in real terms.
## Start Building Today
The Wallet PnL API is now live on BDS. Combine it with our Net Worth and Wallet Token Balance APIs to deliver the most complete wallet intelligence available on Solana.

# The Most Powerful Net Worth APIs on Solana Are Here
With two new endpoints Net Worth Chart and Net Worth Details, Birdeye Data Services offers a comprehensive solution for wallet portfolio valuation in Solana.
3 min 
read
!The Most Powerful Net Worth APIs on Solana Are Here
Wallet net worth is one of the most critical data points in any crypto app. Traders, dashboards, wallets, tax tools, and analytics platforms all rely on accurate portfolio valuation ‚Äî not just totals, but token-level context and history.
With the launch of two new endpoints **Net Worth** **Chart** and **Net Worth Details** , Birdeye Data Services now offers a complete set of net worth APIs on Solana. Together with the previously launched **Current Net Worth** , these endpoints form the **Net Worth Combo** , the most comprehensive solution for wallet portfolio valuation in the ecosystem.
## Current Net Worth
The Current Net Worth endpoint answers the most immediate question: _what is this wallet worth right now?_ It returns the total USD value of a wallet along with a token-by-token breakdown, including balances and valuations.
This makes it the go-to API for powering live dashboards, wallet apps, or quick portfolio checks where users need accurate, real-time visibility.
## Net Worth Chart
While snapshots are useful, developers often need to show how a wallet has performed over time. The Net Worth Chart endpoint provides historical portfolio values, allowing you to track growth, visualize P&L, and highlight trends across any time window.
The data is immediately chart-ready, allowing you to generate historical net worth charts that visualize balance trends across any timeframe. This enables features like time-based analytics and user benchmarking, all without requiring you to piece together raw transaction data.
## Net Worth Details
For even deeper analysis, the Net Worth Details endpoint goes beyond totals and provides token-level history. You can see how individual assets contributed to a wallet‚Äôs net worth at different points in time, making it valuable for:
 * P&L attribution at the token level
 * Advanced portfolio analysis
 * Tax and compliance reporting

By tying wallet value changes to specific tokens, this endpoint makes it easy to explain _why_ a portfolio grew or declined.
## Why the Combo Matters
Separately, each of these APIs solves a critical problem. Together, they deliver the full picture of wallet net worth on Solana: a real-time snapshot, a historical timeline, and detailed token-level attribution.
For developers, that means less engineering overhead, fewer custom calculations, and a much faster path to building high-quality wallet features into your product.
## Start Building Today
The Net Worth Combo is live now and ready to use! Explore the docs:
 * Current Net Worth
 * Net Worth Chart
 * Net Worth Details

# Wallet First Tx Funded API: Trace Wallet Origins on Solana
The Wallet ‚Äì First Tx Funded API for Solana, will help discover the very first funding event of one or more wallets, from onboarding analysis to fraud detection
2 min 
read
!Wallet First Tx Funded API: Trace Wallet Origins on Solana
When analyzing wallets, one of the most common questions is: _When did this address first receive funds?_
Whether you‚Äôre mapping user onboarding, tracing token adoption, or flagging potentially malicious wallets, the first incoming transaction is often the key to understanding how that wallet began its journey.
That‚Äôs exactly what the new Wallet First Tx Funded API delivers.
## A New Lens on Wallet Behavior
The endpoint gives you the very first funding event for any wallet on Solana. For up to **50 wallets per request** , you‚Äôll get the transaction hash, block time, funded amount, token address, and raw balance details.
Need to track the first time a wallet receives a specific token? Add the `**token_address**`filter, and the API will return the initial funding event for that asset only.
## Why This Matters
This isn‚Äôt just about timestamps. By pinpointing when wallets first get funded, developers can:
 * Analyze growth cohorts and track adoption curves
 * Detect newly activated wallets that may pose security risks
 * Study early token distribution patterns to uncover adoption signals

From growth teams to security researchers, the insights from this endpoint go far beyond surface-level wallet data.
## Start Building Today
Using it is simple: send a POST request to `/wallet/v2/tx/first-funded` with a list of wallet addresses (up to 50). Optionally add a token filter. The response comes back with full transaction details and funding data.

# Supported networks
**API Endpoint: /defi/networks**
**Description:** This endpoint allows users to query the currently supported networks of Birdeye Data Services.
**Request Method:** GET
**Request URL:**
plaintext
```
https://public-api.birdeye.so/defi/networks
```

**Request Headers:**
plaintext
```
accept: application/json
X-API-KEY: YOUR_API_KEY
```

**Response:** The response includes a list of historical API call identifiers and the remaining time until the package's expiration.
**Example Request:**
Bash
```
curl --request GET \
     --url https://public-api.birdeye.so/defi/networks \
 		 -H 'X-API-KEY: YOUR_API_KEY'
```

**Current supported networks:**
JSON
```
{
  "data": [
    "solana",
    "ethereum",
    "arbitrum",
    "avalanche",
    "bsc",
    "optimism",
    "polygon",
    "base",
    "zksync",
    "sui",
    "monad"
  ],
  "success": true
}
```

**Notes for SUI network**
 1. Not supported APIs:

 * Wallet APIs (v1/wallet/)
 * defi/token_security
 * defi/token_creation_info
 * defi/v2/tokens/all

 1. Data not reruned in tokenoverview endpoint

 * mc
 * supply

 1. API defi/price & API defi/token_overview

 * The liquidity calculation is currently different for this endpoint. The improvement will be release on the version 2 of both two above APIs.

# Trending tokens
Retrieve a dynamic list of trending tokens.
# 
*API Endpoint:** /defi/token_trending
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/trending-tokens#api-endpoint-defitoken_trending)
**Description:** This endpoint retrieves a dynamic and up-to-date list of trending tokens based on specified sorting criteria. Users can discover the hottest tokens in the market by sorting them by rank, liquidity, or 24-hour trading volume in USD. The response provides essential details such as rank, liquidity, and 24-hour volume, making it easy to stay ahead in the fast-paced world of cryptocurrency.
## 
Request
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/trending-tokens#request)
**Request Method:** GET
**Data Coverage:** Multi-chain
**Request URL:**
undefined
```
<https://public-api.birdeye.so/defi/token_trending?sort_by=rank&sort_type=asc&offset=0&limit=3>
```

**Request Headers:**
```
accept: application/json
x-chain: any chains that Birdeye supports. Example: solana, ethereum
X-API-KEY: YOUR_API_KEY
```

**Parameters:**
Key | Data Type | Details | Example 
---|---|---|--- 
`sort_by` | string | The attribute to sort the tokens by. Supported values: `rank` (default), `liquidity`, `volume24hUSD`. | rank 
`sort_type` | string | The order to sort the tokens in. Supported values: `asc` (default), `desc`. | asc 
`offset` | integer | The number of records to skip from the start. Default is `0`. | 0 
`limit` | integer | The maximum number of records to return. Supported values: `<= 20`, Default is `20`. | 3 
## 
Response
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/trending-tokens#response)
The response provides a list of trending tokens based on the specified sorting criteria, along with their rank, liquidity, and 24-hour volume in USD.
**Example Request:**
Bash
```
curl --request GET \
     --url 'https://public-api.birdeye.so/defi/token_trending?sort_by=rank&sort_type=asc&offset=0&limit=3' \
     --header 'X-API-KEY: YOUR_API_KEY' \
     --header 'x-chain: solana'
```

**Example Response:**
JSON
```
{  
    "success": true,  
    "data": {  
        "updateUnixTime": 1720012620,  
        "updateTime": "2024-07-03T13:17:00",  
        "tokens": [  
            {  
                "address": "EphmxhQwGYtC3qMBLjywoF7PcCp6XnbBhUVLzz966UR7",  
                "decimals": 6,  
                "liquidity": 572411.039201234,  
                "logoURI": "https://img.fotofolio.xyz/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgateway.pinata.cloud%2Fipfs%2FQmWZ2nLQNzH4vpdTjuHZizCxW9RfXJwx7GXCQVPqL2vmB4",  
                "name": "Barron Trump",  
                "symbol": "BARRON",  
                "volume24hUSD": 2793145.1025349544,  
                "rank": 0  
            },  
            {  
                "address": "J4cojhnAdenazghRaNPzQY8vCF6iYgKPpJRifjU2CMNp",  
                "decimals": 6,  
                "liquidity": 547495.7322365416,  
                "logoURI": "https://img.fotofolio.xyz/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgateway.pinata.cloud%2Fipfs%2FQmY3BproM1BpQ4ETvrK4Wxre1Zy4fMjevd6qQD6mctLdLG",  
                "name": "BAKED",  
                "symbol": "BAKED",  
                "volume24hUSD": 3527918.040501778,  
                "rank": 1  
            },  
            {  
                "address": "BUvyaUe6P1dbzqjBMFaqcHKxUGWdBBm2ezRW6RipB6j4",  
                "decimals": 6,  
                "liquidity": 425092.85064021597,  
                "logoURI": "https://img.fotofolio.xyz/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgateway.pinata.cloud%2Fipfs%2FQmRqKFu4RTDag5MyHBkUniPSYwGXw4aDPY8dtdgyqxQVfc",  
                "name": "Windoge98",  
                "symbol": "Windoge98",  
                "volume24hUSD": 1380656.3887991658,  
                "rank": 2  
            }  
        ],  
        "total": 1000  
    }  
}
```

**Response Parameters:**
Key | Data Type | Details | Example 
---|---|---|--- 
`updateUnixTime` | integer | The Unix timestamp of the most recent update. | 1720012620 
`updateTime` | string | The human-readable time of the most recent update. | "2024-07-03T13:17:00" 
`tokens` | array | The list of trending tokens. | 
`tokens[].address` | string | The token address. | "EphmxhQwGYtC3qMBLjywoF7PcCp6XnbBhUVLzz966UR7" 
`tokens[].decimals` | integer | The number of decimal places for the token. | 6 
`tokens[].liquidity` | float | The liquidity of the token. | 572411.039201234 
`tokens[].logoURI` | string | The URI of the token's logo. | "<https://img.fotofolio.xyz/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgateway.pinata.cloud%2Fipfs%2FQmWZ2nLQNzH4vpdTjuHZizCxW9RfXJwx7GXCQVPqL2vmB4>" 
`tokens[].name` | string | The name of the token. | "Barron Trump" 
`tokens[].symbol` | string | The symbol of the token. | "BARRON" 
`tokens[].volume24hUSD` | float | The 24-hour trading volume of the token in USD. | 2793145.1025349544 
`tokens[].rank` | integer | The rank of the token based on the sorting criteria. | 0 
`total` | integer | The total number of trending tokens. | 1000 
**Note:** This endpoint provides a real-time trending list of tokens, making it easy for users to identify and track the most active and liquid tokens in the market.

# Authentication & API Keys
To utilize the Birdeye's APIs, an API key is required for authentication. You can obtain an API key by signing up for a Birdeye.so account and generating an API key in your BDS Dashboard. Include this API key in the headers of your API requests for authentication.
Here's a step-by-step guide on how to obtain an API key:
# 
1 - Create a Birdeye Account
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/authentication-api-keys#1---create-a-birdeye-account)
 * A single Birdeye account can be used for both accessing website birdeye.so and using Birdeye Data Services (BDS).
 * You can create your Birdeye account using one of two methods:
 * Using birdeye.so sign-up page: <https://birdeye.so/user/sign-up>. Please check out detailed instructions HERE.
 * Using BDS sign-up page: <https://bds.birdeye.so/auth/sign-up>. 
**Note** : Both methods above result in one single account, and that account can be used in both systems. It is not possible to create two account in those two systems with the same email address.

# 
2 - Get your API Keys
[](https://docs.birdeye.so/docs/authentication-api-keys#2---get-your-api-keys)
 * **Log in to your BDS account:** use your email and password to log into BDS Dashboard using this link: <https://bds.birdeye.so/auth/sign-in>
 * **Access the Security Tab:** On your Dashboard, look for a section labeled "Security" or similar. This is where you'll find options related to API keys and security settings.

 * **Generate API Key:** Within the Security section, you'll find an option to generate an API key. This might be labeled as "Generate Key" or something similar. Click on this option to initiate the API key generation process.

 * **Configure Key Settings (Optional):** Depending on the platform, you might have the option to configure settings for your API key. This could include specifying the access permissions or adding a name/description to the key for better organization.

 * **Generate the Key:** After configuring any optional settings, click the "Generate" or "Create" button to generate your API key. The system will create a unique API key associated with your Birdeye account.
 * **Copy the API Key:** Once the API key is generated, you'll typically see it displayed on the screen. It might be a long string of alphanumeric characters. Make sure to copy this key and keep it in a secure place. You'll need to include this key in the headers of your API requests for authentication.

And that's it! You now have your API key from Birdeye.so, which you can use to authenticate your API requests and access the services provided by the Birdeye.so APIs.
